column4: Magic is Perl's way of enhancing variables.
This mechanism lets the user add extra data to any variable and hook syntactical operations (such as access
column5: assignment or destruction) that can be applied to it.
you can add your own magic to any variable without having to write a single line of XS.

column4: You'll realize that these magic variables look a lot like tied variables.

column5: as tied variables are implemented as a special kind of magic
column6: just like any 'irregular' Perl variable : scalars like C<$!>

column4: They all share the same underlying C API
column5: and this module gives you direct access to it.
the magic made available by this module differs from tieing and overloading in several ways :

column4: Magic is not copied on assignment.

column5: not values (as for blessed references).

column4: Magic does not replace the original semantics.
Magic callbacks usually get triggered before the original action takes place
column5: and cannot prevent it from happening.

column4: This also makes catching individual events easier than with C<tie>
column5: where you have to provide fallbacks methods for all actions by usually inheriting from the correct C<Tie::Std*> class and overriding individual methods in your own class.

column4: You can safely apply different kinds of magics to the same variable
column5: and each of them will be invoked successively.

column4: The same magic can be applied on scalars
column5: arrays

column4: But the same hook (see below for a list) may trigger differently depending on the type of the variable.
Magic is invisible at Perl level.
